In June 2016 NATO defence ministers approved a Comprehensive Assistance Package (CAP) for Ukraine in order to support reforms aimed at building stronger security structures. In the following month a meeting of the NATO-Ukraine Commission at the level of heads of state and of government reiterated full support for the Minsk Agreements and for the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission deployed to Ukraine to monitor and calm the conflict, and welcomed the adoption in June by the Ukrainian authorities of the NATO principles-based Strategic Defence Bulletin, a roadmap for defence reform.

Meanwhile, at the end of July 2014 the NATO Secretary-General stated that the USA had briefed the NAC that Russia was in violation of its obligation under the 1988 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty not to possess, to produce, or to flight-test a ground-launched cruise missile with a range capability of 500 km-5,500 km, or to possess or produce launchers of such missiles. The September Wales (UK) summit meeting of NATO heads of state and of government reaffirmed the Alliance’s ongoing suspension of all practical civilian and military co-operation with Russia, and supported sanctions imposed against that country—in view of its destabilizing actions against Ukraine—by the EU, G7 and other international groupings. In October 2015 the NAC expressed deep concern over escalating Russian military activity in Syria, with particular reference to attacks by the Russian Air Force on Hama, Homs and Idlib, on the grounds that these had not targeted Islamic State, and had caused casualties among the civilian population. The Council urged Russia to promote a political solution to the conflict in Syria, and to use military force to target solely Islamic State and to halt attacks on the Syrian opposition and civilians. The Council also protested against recent Russian violations of Turkish airspace. In late November an extraordinary meeting of the NAC emphasized solidarity with Türkiye following the shooting down of a Russian plane that had entered its airspace.

The July 2016 meeting of NATO heads of state and of government (and Montenegro) noted the continuing impact of destabilizing actions and policies by Russia, citing the annexation of and Russian military build-up in Crimea; destabilization of eastern Ukraine; violation of sovereign borders by force; incursions into NATO airspace; provocative military operations near NATO borders, including in the Eastern Mediterranean and the Baltic and Black Sea areas; and military intervention in Syria. NATO leaders reaffirmed, accordingly, the suspension of practical and military co-operation with Russia, the deployment of a forward presence in eastern Alliance territories, and willingness to pursue political dialogue and to maintain military lines of communication with Russia. A meeting of the NRC convened in July 2016 addressed the need fully to implement the Minsk Agreements on Ukraine; the outcomes of the recent Warsaw Summit; and the situation in Afghanistan. A proposal was put forward by the Russian delegation aimed at enhancing air safety in the Baltic Sea area. In December the NRC meeting addressed, inter alia , transparency and minimizing the risk of misunderstanding and miscalculation during military activities. The NATO delegation emphasized the destabilizing impact of the excessive use of `snap’ military exercises held without forewarning, noting the need to adhere to the rules governing the notification and observation of such exercises that are enshrined in the OSCE Vienna Document. Participants in the meeting recommended that the NRC should contribute to updating the Vienna Document.

In July 2017 then President Petro Poroshenko of Ukraine requested the initiation of discussions on developing an action plan that might pave the way for Ukraine’s eventual accession to NATO membership. The inaugural meeting of a NATO-Ukraine Platform on Countering Hybrid Warfare was convened in October; the Platform aimed to strengthen Ukraine’s capacity to resist hybrid threats (including terrorist and hacking attacks, and hostile media campaigns). In July 2018, at the Brussels meeting of NATO heads of state and of government, NATO leaders and Ukraine condemned ongoing human rights abuses and discrimination by the de facto Russian authorities in Crimea, including against Crimean Tatars, Ukrainians and members of other distinct ethnic, religious or political groupings. They urged Russia and the de facto authorities in Ukraine to grant international monitoring organizations access to Crimea, as well as to free Ukrainian detainees held in Russia, Crimea and in those parts of eastern Ukraine that remained under the control of Russia-supported militants. Russia’s recent construction of the Kerch Strait Bridge connecting Russia and Crimea was condemned as a further violation of Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity.

In mid-March 2018 the NAC determined to reduce the size of the Russian mission to NATO and to expel hitherto accredited staff, in response to a recent attack perpetrated in Salisbury, UK, against a retired Russian military intelligence officer and his daughter, using a military-grade nerve agent developed in Russia. The attack was alleged by the UK Government to have been conducted with the knowledge of the Russian authorities (they, however, strongly denied this), and represented the first offensive use of a nerve agent on NATO territory. In May—in view of the conclusion by a Joint Investigation Team (a co-operative undertaking between the Netherlands, Malaysia, Ukraine, Australia and Belgium) that a Russian missile launcher had been used in the July 2014 shooting down of Malaysian Airlines flight MH17—NATO reiterated its full support for the investigation. (In November 2022, following a trial in the Netherlands initiated by Dutch public prosecutors, two Russians and one Ukrainian separatist were found guilty, in absentia, of murdering all of the plane’s passengers and crew and were sentenced to life terms of imprisonment; their arrests were ordered.)

In November 2018, at the request of Ukraine, a meeting of the NATO-Ukraine Commission was held to address escalating tensions in the Kerch Strait, where recently Russia had opened fire against and seized the crews of three Ukrainian vessels. NATO called on Russia to allow Ukraine freedom of navigation in the Kerch Strait and Sea of Azov, and to ensure unhindered access to Ukrainian ports. NATO also urged the immediate release of the captured naval personnel, emphasizing that the use of military force against Ukrainian ships and their personnel was not warranted. It reiterated that Russia must end its support to militant groupings active in Ukraine and withdraw all its forces from that country’s territory, and that Russia’s illegitimate annexation and subsequent militarization of Crimea was unacceptable. NATO noted that the Russia-Ukraine crisis had led to the ongoing punitive sanctions regime against Russia, and also drew attention to the recent significant reinforcement of the Allies’ collective defence capabilities. This position was emphasized by a statement on Crimea released by the NAC in March 2019. In June 2020 the NAC designated Ukraine as an Enhanced Opportunities Partner under the Partnership Interoperability Initiative. In July Ukraine participated, with sea, air, land and amphibious forces from 12 NATO Allies, in NATO’s annual Black Sea `Sea Breeze’ exercises. During that year NATO delivered medical supplies and extended financial assistance to help Ukraine counter the COVID-19 crisis.

In December 2018 NATO ministers responsible for foreign affairs declared that Russia had developed and deployed a (`9M729’) missile system that violated the 1998 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty and posed a considerable risk to Euro-Atlantic security. On 1 February 2019, in response to Russia’s violation, the USA suspended its obligations under the Treaty (full withdrawal took effect in August); on the following day President Putin announced that Russia had also formally suspended its participation, and would develop new missiles. In May 2020 the NATO Secretary-General stated continued support for the 1992 Open Skies Treaty, following an announcement by the US Administration that it was to withdraw its participation given Russian non-compliance; the withdrawal took effect in November. In January 2021 Russia formally announced its impending withdrawal. In late May the new US Administration of Joe Biden informed Russia that it would not rejoin. On 2 June the Russian Duma (parliamentary assembly) passed legislation that provided for Russia’s withdrawal from the Treaty.

In February 2021 the NAC welcomed the extension by a further five years, until 5 February 2026, of the term of the Treaty on Measures for the Further Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms (known as the New START Treaty), which had been in effect between the Russian Federation and the USA since February 2011. (The New START Treaty had replaced a previous START Treaty, which was in force between the two countries between 1994-2009.) In October 2021 NATO expelled eight members of Russia’s Belgium-based mission to the organization, describing them as undeclared intelligence officers. In response the Russian authorities decided that from 1 November the accreditation of personnel at NATO’s mission in Moscow would be withdrawn, and that liaison and information offices hitherto maintained by NATO in Moscow were to be closed.

At a NATO-Ukraine Commission meeting held in April 2021 concern was stated over Russia’s intensified military presence in and around Ukraine and over violations by Russian-supported militants of the ceasefire in eastern Ukraine. (An agreement on measures to strengthen the ceasefire regime had entered into effect in late July 2020.) Calling on Russia to de-escalate the situation, the NATO Secretary-General emphasized that Russia’s annexation of Crimea would not be recognized by the NATO allies. In December 2021 the NAC expressed grave concern at the build-up of Russian troops and military equipment close to the Ukrainian border, and insisted that the Alliance would respond to any aggression against its members or allied partners. Russia’s President Putin, meanwhile, issued a demand that membership of NATO should not be extended to any former Soviet states, and that the Alliance should halt military co-operation initiatives in eastern Europe. A session of the NATO-Ukraine Commission was held on 10 January 2022 to discuss the escalating crisis. The first meeting of the NRC in more than two years was convened on 12 January as a platform to address the situation in Ukraine and wider security concerns. NATO demands for a de-escalation of the build-up of border troops and respect for Ukraine’s territorial integrity were reiterated, as were Russian proposals that NATO withdraw troops and equipment from former Soviet bloc Alliance members and guarantee that the Alliance would not be further enlarged. In mid-January the NATO Communications and Information Agency and Ukrainian authorities signed an updated Memorandum of Agreement to govern continuing co-operation on technology-related initiatives.

In late January 2022 the NATO Secretary-General confirmed that NATO had sent a series of written proposals to Russia, ideally to be addressed within the NRC framework, that focused on advancing NATO-Russia relations; Euro-Atlantic regional security (including the situation in and around Ukraine); and risk reduction, arms control, and transparency. On 24 February Russia, with Belarusian support, invaded Ukraine. (See main Activities section.)

In late January 2022 the NATO Secretary-General confirmed that NATO had sent a series of written proposals to Russia, ideally to be addressed within the NRC framework, that focused on advancing NATO-Russia relations; Euro-Atlantic regional security (including the situation in and around Ukraine); and risk reduction, arms control, and transparency. On 21 February the NATO Secretary-General condemned a decision by the Russian authorities to grant formal recognition to the self-proclaimed `Donetsk People’s Republic’ and `Luhansk People’s Republic’ (eastern Ukraine). An extraordinary session of the NATO-Ukraine Commission convened on the following day also deplored the move. An extraordinary session of the NAC was convened on 24 February, called for by Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania and Slovakia in the context of Article 4 of the North Atlantic Treaty, in response to Russia’s full-scale military invasion of Ukraine earlier in that day. The Council strongly deplored Russia’s act of aggression, and also condemned Belarus for enabling Russia’s assault on Ukraine. The Council called on Russia immediately to cease its military action, to withdraw its forces from Ukraine, to respect international humanitarian law, and to allow unhindered safe humanitarian access to all affected civilians. The Council confirmed that Allied defence plans were being activated, including the deployment of defensive land, air and maritime rapid response reinforcements to the Alliance’s eastern zone. An extraordinary summit of NATO heads of state was held in a virtual format on 25 February, with invited participation by the leaders of Finland, Sweden and the EU, to address `the gravest threat to Euro-Atlantic security in decades’. The summit deplored the loss of life and the destruction ongoing in Ukraine, and called on Russia to withdraw its military forces immediately, noting that Russia would be held accountable globally as an aggressor, and Belarus as Russia’s enabler. The summit emphasized that the regime of Russian President Putin was focused beyond Ukraine and had demanded legally binding agreements that would prevent further enlargement of NATO, while calling for troops and military infrastructure to be withdrawn from the territories of all Allies that had gained membership since 1997. The summit committed to continuing to assist Ukraine, and to strengthening (rather than reducing, as demanded by Russia) support for, inter alia Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia and Moldova. Meanwhile, in response to the participation by the Finnish and Swedish leaders in the summit, Putin threatened that `military consequences’ would ensue for Finland and Sweden, should they join NATO. In mid-March an extraordinary meeting of NATO ministers responsible for defence determined to continue to support Ukraine through the provision of military supplies, as well as financial and humanitarian assistance, and to implement measures to strengthen NATO’s collective security. An in-person extraordinary summit meeting was convened on 24 March. Leaders announced that, in addition to the recent deployment of an intensified military presence in eastern zones, four new multinational battlegroups would be stationed in Bulgaria, Hungary, Romania, and Slovakia. The transformation of NATO to adapt to the new gravely dangerous strategic reality would now be effected, including through enhanced collective exercises, and a strengthening of situational awareness, of cyber capabilities, of capacity to deter disinformation, of civil preparedness, and of readiness to repel biological, chemical, radiological and nuclear threats.

Meeting in Brussels in early April 2022—with participation by representatives of Finland, Sweden, Georgia, the EU, Australia, Japan, the Republic of Korea (South Korea) and New Zealand—NATO ministers responsible for foreign affairs determined to enhance support to Ukraine, to extend tailored assistance to regional partners under pressure from Russia’s aggression against Ukraine, and also to assist partners in the Asia-Pacific impacted by the global impacts of the ongoing crisis. The Allies stated support for an international investigation to be conducted into the murders of civilians in Bucha and other Ukrainian locations recently liberated from Russian control. They also approved a Charter underpinning the new DIANA network of technology innovation centres. In mid-May NATO foreign ministers, again convened in Brussels, discussed possible accession to the Alliance by Finland and Sweden; formal applications for membership were submitted simultaneously by Finland and Sweden on 18 May. Türkiye indicated opposition to this development. During May an intensive series of NATO military exercises was conducted in member states, from the Baltic region to the Balkans. In June a trilateral memorandum was concluded between Finland, Sweden and Türkiye, in which the two applicant countries made commitments (including on the extradition of suspected terrorists) with respect to Türkiye’s security concerns relating to the separatist Kurdistan Workers’ Party—Partiya Karkeren Kurdistan.

At a summit of NATO heads of state and of government that was held in Madrid, Spain, in June 2022, Finland and Sweden were formally invited to join the Alliance. Recognizing that a fundamental shift in defence and deterrence was needed to respond to the new security reality, which was to require increased defence investment, a new Strategic Concept was endorsed by the summit. This included strengthening the Alliance’s forward defences, enhancing battle groups in its eastern areas, transforming the NRF by mid-2024 into a stronger, more versatile multinational and multi-domain Allied Reaction Force (ARF), and increasing the number of NATO high readiness forces to more than 300,000 troops. Russia was identified as the `most significant and direct threat’ to the security and stability of the Euro-Atlantic area, and `systemic competition’ was noted from China: it was noted that a strategic partnership was developing between Russia and China, and that both states were at the vanguard of an authoritarian challenge to the rules-based international order. Longer-term military and financial support for Ukraine was agreed, and a NATO Innovation Fund was launched, to advance the use of new technology in strengthening international security. The European Union (EU) was deemed a `unique and essential’ partner for NATO in supporting international peace and security. On 5 July 2022 accession protocols for Finland and Sweden were signed by the NATO member states’ Permanent Representatives; ratification of the protocols was then required by the member states’ national legislatures.

In early September 2022 the NAC strongly condemned a recent cyber attack—believed to have been perpetrated by Iran—against Albania’s national information infrastructure. On 23 September the NAC denounced a manoeuvre by the Russian authorities to stage in regions of Ukraine that were under or partly under Russian military control—i.e. Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporizhzhya and Kherson—non-democratic `referenda’ on accession to the Russian Federation. A recent Russian decision to enforce a partial national military mobilization was noted as an escalation of the war against Ukraine. Furthermore, `irresponsible nuclear rhetoric’ by Russia was condemned. Towards the end of the month the NAC stated deep collective concern at recent apparent sabotage, in international waters in the Baltic Sea, to the Nordstream 1 and Nordstream 2 gas pipelines that run from northeastern Russia to western Europe. The Council emphasized that the ensuing gas leaks posed a risk to shipping and to the environment. On 30 September, in contravention of international law, Russia’s President Putin signed decrees that purported to incorporate Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporizhzhya and Kherson into Russia. On the same day Ukraine submitted a formal application for NATO membership. The NATO Secretary-General termed Russia’s annexation of Ukrainian territory illegal and the most serious escalation thus far of the conflict.

In mid-November 2022 an emergency meeting of the NAC was convened to address an explosion on the previous day in eastern Poland, close to the border with Ukraine, which had reportedly killed two Polish civilians. The meeting concluded that no deliberate attack had been undertaken and preliminary investigations indicated it had been caused by Ukrainian air defence systems. In late November NATO’s ministers responsible for foreign affairs and their Finnish and Swedish counterparts, gathered in Bucharest, Romania, condemned Russia’s `reckless nuclear rhetoric’, ongoing energy blackmail and subversion of the rules-based international order; and reaffirmed solidarity with Poland and their resolute will to support Ukraine’s post-war reconstruction and reform process.

In early February 2023 the NAC noted with concern a decision by Russia at that time to suspend its participation in (and legally-binding obligations under) the New START Treaty, emphasizing that the treaty made an important contribution to international stability. NATO Allies and also Japan undertook a co-ordinated humanitarian operation to deliver humanitarian aid to Türkiye, in response to devastating earthquakes that struck southern areas of that country in February. In that month 16 NATO allies and Finland and Sweden agreed to join a new Alliance Persistent Surveillance from Space (APSS) initiative. A Critical Undersea Infrastructure Coordination Cell was established in February at NATO’s headquarters, and in March a new NATO-EU Task Force on Resilience of Critical Infrastructure was initiated, to defend against Russia’s weaponization of energy supplies. In mid-March, following a meeting with his Finnish counterpart, Türkiye’s President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan announced that, as Finland had taken `authentic and concrete’ measures to address Türkiye’s security concerns (as agreed in the June 2022 Trilateral Memorandum), ratification of that country’s NATO application would proceed through the Turkish legislature; this was effected at the end of March 2023. On 4 April Finland formally deposited its instrument of accession as the 31st NATO member state. In early June the NAC condemned a decision by Russia to withdraw from the CFE Treaty on 7 November. In late June, in response to a short-lived mutiny against Russia’s military high command by the Wagner Group (a Russian private paramilitary and security contractor), NATO’s Secretary-General observed that the Russian leadership’s use of mercenary forces exemplified the scale of its strategic mistake in waging war on Ukraine.

The 2023 summit of NATO heads of state and of government was held on 12 July, in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius. The leaders determined to establish a NATO Maritime Centre for the Security of Critical Undersea Infrastructure, within NATO’s Maritime Command. At that time the inaugural meeting was convened, with participation by the NATO leaders and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, of the NATO-Ukraine Council, a new format for bilateral consultations. It was affirmed that Ukraine would eventually accede to NATO, and that the usual requirement for a MAP would be waived. A new assistance package for Ukraine was agreed, aimed at upgrading national equipment and protocols, and enabling full interoperability between Ukrainian and NATO forces: a formal membership invitation was to be issued to the country once those conditions were achieved, and the agreement of all Allies secured. The NATO leaders also met with their counterparts from Australia, Japan, New Zealand, South Korea and the EU, and the value of co-operation between NATO, EU and Indo-Pacific partners was emphasized.

In October 2023, in response to damage perpetrated against critical undersea infrastructure in the Baltic Sea, NATO intensified surveillance and reconnaissance flights in the area. A Digital Ocean Vision, aimed at enhancing NATO’s maritime situational awareness, from the seabed to space, was endorsed at that time by the Allied ministers responsible for defence. Meanwhile, Russia determined at that time to revoke its ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (which had been effected in 2000)—to ensure parity with the USA, which had signed but not as yet ratified the treaty; relevant legislation was then accelerated through Russia’s legislature. The inaugural ministerial-level meeting of the NATO-Ukraine Council was convened in November 2023. It was reported at the end of December that NATO air forces across Europe had scrambled on more than 300 occasions during 2023 to intercept Russian military aircraft nearing Alliance airspace (predominantly over the Baltic Sea).

At an ambassadorial-level meeting of the NATO-Ukraine Council that was held in early January 2024, at Ukraine’s request, the Allies reaffirmed commitment to providing Ukraine with large-scale military, economic, and humanitarian assistance during the year ahead, including a focus on enhancing Ukraine’s air defences. In mid-January a meeting of the NATO Military Committee, plus Sweden, confirmed that the new ARF would be headquartered from mid-2024 (on an interim basis) in Italy. After a protracted delay Türkiye finally approved Sweden’s Accession Protocol in late January 2024. Hitherto, Hungary’s endorsement of Sweden’s accession had been deferred. (In March 2023 a Hungarian government spokesperson had cited as the cause of the postponement grievances over criticism by the Swedish Government of the political agenda of the Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán.) In January 2024, at the time of Türkiye’s advancement of Sweden’s accession process, Orbán—who had assured the other Allies that Hungary would not prevent Sweden from joining NATO—issued an invitation to his Swedish counterpart, Ulf Kristersson, to visit the Hungarian capital, Budapest, to discuss the situation. In late February, in Budapest, Orbán and Kristersson concluded a new bilateral military deal. The Hungarian legislature approved Sweden’s Accession Protocol and that country’s President signed it on 5 March. Sweden deposited its instrument of accession with the US Administration on 7 March, marking its formal admission as NATO’s 32nd member state.

p-group.heading: NATO-Georgia Commission (NGC)
p-group.p: In August 2008 an extraordinary meeting of the NAC, convened to discuss an escalation of conflict in Georgia, expressed solidarity with Georgia's actions to counter attacks by separatist forces in Abkhazia and South Ossetia and deplored as disproportionate the use of force by Russia. The NAC subsequently established the NGC, to strengthen co-operation and political dialogue between the two sides and to oversee Georgia's future application for NATO membership. The NAC also agreed that NATO would support Georgia in assessing damage to civil infrastructure, as well as in re-establishing an air traffic system and advising on cyber defence issues. The NGC—which held its inaugural meeting in the Georgian capital, Tbilisi, in September—comprises Georgia and all NATO member states, and convenes regularly at the level of ambassadors and military representatives, periodically at the level of foreign and defence ministers and chiefs of staff, and occasionally at summit level. A NATO Liaison Office was inaugurated in Tbilisi in October 2010. In October 2013 the NATO Secretary-General noted with concern the construction by Russia of fences and other obstacles along administrative boundary lines within Georgia, deeming this to be provocative, and urging their removal. He also urged Russia to reverse its recognition of the South Ossetia and Abkhazia regions of Georgia as independent states. NATO refused to recognize parliamentary elections held in South Ossetia in June 2014. In September the Wales, UK, summit meeting of Alliance heads of state and of government determined to extend to Georgia (as well as to Moldova) the implementation of a new Defence and Related Security Capacity Building Initiative, and endorsed a Substantial NATO-Georgia Package (SNGP) that included defence capacity building, training, strengthened liaison, and enhanced opportunities for interoperability. Georgia was to make forces available to the NRF in 2015. (This was achieved in October of that year.) Georgia also offered its participation in the NATO training mission `Resolute Support’, deployed from 2015-21 in Afghanistan. In March 2015 the NATO Secretary-General reaffirmed the status of South Ossetia and Abkhazia as integral parts of Georgia and urged Russia to reverse its recognition of those territories as independent entities. A NATO-Georgia Joint Training and Evaluation Centre was inaugurated at the Krtsanisi Military Facility, Georgia, in August. A NATO-Georgia military exercise—`Noble Partner’ (described by Russia as `provocative’)—has been regularly undertaken at the Vaziani military base, near Tbilisi, since 2016. In July of that year the NGC approved increased support for military training and education in Georgia, provisionally to be financed through a new trust fund, and for strategic communications. The SNGP was upgraded in late 2020. In January 2021 the NATO Secretary-General stated that key joint priorities were secure communications; training and exercises; and enhancing maritime support and situational awareness. Under NATO’s Partnership Interoperability Initiative (q.v.) Georgia is an `Enhanced Opportunities Partner’. The April 2008 decision to invite Georgia to apply for MAP status has been reconfirmed by subsequent summits of NATO heads of state and of government.

Meeting in early April 2022 NATO ministers responsible for foreign affairs gave consideration to further enhancing the SNGP—for example with respect to secure communications, cyber defence and situational awareness—to support Georgia in building resilience, in the context of the regional threat posed by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

p-group.heading: Mediterranean Dialogue
p-group.p: NATO’s Mediterranean Dialogue was established in 1994. The Madrid summit meeting in July 1997 endorsed the establishment of a Mediterranean Co-operation Group to enhance NATO relations with Egypt, Israel, Jordan, Mauritania, Morocco and Tunisia. The Group was to provide a forum for consultation between the two groupings and to promote co-operation in training, scientific research and information ex­change. Algeria joined the Dialogue in February 2000. At a meeting held in April 2006 between the NAC and representatives of the seven Mediterranean Dialogue countries, the latter were encouraged to formulate Individual Co-operation Programmes (ICPs) as a framework for future co-operation. In November a NATO Training Co-operation Initiative was inaugurated, extending defence and specialist training and expertise to Mediterranean Dialogue and ICI partner countries in order to help them to strengthen their defence structures and to enhance the interoperability of their armed forces with those of the Alliance. Egypt signed an ICP with NATO in October 2007, and Jordan concluded its ICP in April 2009.

p-group.heading: İstanbul Cooperation Initiative (ICI)
p-group.p: The ICI was initiated by the June 2004 summit meeting, with the aim of promoting broader co-oper­ation with the Middle East. By April 2007 Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates had joined the initiative. An ICI Regional Centre was inaugurated in Kuwait in January 2017.

In March 2016 the Secretaries-General of NATO and the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) met to discuss means of deepening co-operation between the two organizations. The NATO summit meeting convened in July in Warsaw, Poland, welcomed the forthcoming establishment of practical co-operation with the GCC.

p-group.heading: Global Partners
p-group.p: In 2024 NATO’s so-called `partners across the globe’ included: Afghanistan, Australia, Colombia, Iraq, Japan, South Korea, Mongolia, New Zealand and Pakistan. NATO partner countries are represented by heads of diplo­matic missions or liaison officers located at NATO head­quarters in Brussels.

int-org-section.heading: Selected Operations
int-org-section.p: During the 1990s NATO increasingly developed its role as a mechanism for peacekeeping and crisis management. In June 1992 NATO ministers responsible for foreign affairs, meeting in Oslo, Norway, announced the Alliance's readiness to support peacekeeping operations under the aegis of the then CSCE on a case-by-case basis: NATO would make both military resources and expertise available to such operations. In July NATO undertook a maritime operation in the Adriatic Sea to monitor compliance with the UN Security Council's resolutions imposing sanctions against the Yugoslav republics of Serbia and Montenegro. In December NATO ministers responsible for foreign affairs expressed the Alliance's readiness to support peacekeeping operations under the authority of the UN Security Council.

p-group.heading: Former Yugoslavia
p-group.p: From April 1993 NATO fighter and reconnaissance aircraft began patrolling airspace over Bosnia and Herzegovina in order to enforce the UN prohibition of military aerial activity over the country. In addition, from July NATO aircraft provided protective cover for UN troops operating in the `safe areas' established by the UN Security Council. In February 1994 NATO conducted the first of several aerial strikes against artillery positions that were violating heavy weapons exclusion zones imposed around `safe areas' and threatening the civilian populations. Throughout the conflict the Alliance also provided transport, communications and logistics to support UN humanitarian assistance in the region.

The peace accord for the former Yugoslavia, which was initialled in Dayton, Ohio, USA, in November 1995, and signed in Paris, France, in December, provided for the establishment of a NATO-led Implementation Force (IFOR) to ensure compliance with the treaty. In December a joint meeting of allied foreign and defence ministers endorsed the military structure for the mission, entitled Operation Joint Endeavour, which was to involve approximately 60,000 troops from 31 NATO and non-NATO countries. IFOR, which constituted NATO's largest military oper­ation, formally assumed responsi­bility for peacekeeping in Bosnia and Herzegovina from the UN on 20 December. In December 1996 NATO ministers responsible for foreign affairs approved a smaller follow-on operation, with an 18-month mandate, to be known as the Stabilization Force (SFOR). Its principal objective was to maintain a safe environment at a military level to ensure that the civil aspects of the Dayton peace accord could be fully implemented, including the completion of the de-mining process, the repatriation of refugees, and rehabilitation of local infrastructure. The force strength of SFOR was gradually reduced as the security situation in the country improved. The June 2004 summit meeting determined to termin­ate SFOR’s mandate at the end of 2004, and endorsed a new EU mission, EUFOR, in Bosnia and Herzegovina. NATO maintains a military headquarters in Sarajevo, in order to continue to assist the authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina in matters of defence reform.

In March 1998 an emergency session of the NAC was convened at the request of the Albanian Government, which was concerned at the deteriorating security of its border region with the Serbian province of Kosovo and Metohija. In June NATO ministers authorized the formulation of plans for air strikes against Serbian targets. In mid-October, following Security Council condemnation of the humanitarian situation in Kosovo, the NAC agreed on limited air strikes against Serbian targets. At the same time the US envoy to the region, Richard Holbrooke, concluded an agreement with President Milošević to implement the conditions of a UN resolution (1199). A 2,000-member international observer force, under the auspices of the OSCE, was to be established to monitor compliance with the agreement, supported by a NATO Co-ordination Unit, based in the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia (FYRM, now North Macedonia, q.v.), to assist with aerial sur­veillance. A NATO Kosovo Verification Command Centre was established in Kumanovo, north-east FYRM, in November.

On 24 March 1999 an aerial offensive against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (which was renamed Serbia and Montenegro in 2003 and divided into separate states of Montenegro and Serbia in 2006) was initiated by NATO, with the declared aim of reducing that country's capacity to commit attacks on the Albanian population. In early April 1999 NATO ambassadors agreed to dispatch 8,000 troops, as an ACE Mobile Force Land operation, to provide humanitarian assistance to the estimated 300,000 refugees in Albania at that time and to provide transportation to relieve overcrowded camps, in particular in border areas. Refugees in the FYRM were to be assisted by the existing NATO contingent (numbering some 12,000 troops), which was permitted by the authorities in that country to construct new camps for an estimated 100,000 displaced Kosovans. An additional 1,000 troops were transferred from the FYRM to Albania in mid-May in order to construct a camp to provide for a further 65,000 refugees. NATO's 50th anniversary summit meeting, held in Washington, DC, in April, issued a statement declaring the deter­mination of all Alliance members to increase economic and military pressure on President Milošević to withdraw forces from Kosovo, and agreed to prevent shipments of petroleum reaching Serbia through Montenegro. On 9 June a Military Technical Agreement was signed between NATO and the Federal Republic of Yugo­slavia, incorporating a timetable for the withdrawal of all Serbian security personnel. On the following day the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1244, which authorized an international security presence in Kosovo, the Kosovo Peace Implementation Force (KFOR), under NATO command, and an international civilian presence, the UN Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo (UNMIK). The NAC subsequently suspended the air strike campaign, which, by that time, had involved some 38,000 sorties. An initial 20,000 KFOR troops entered Kosovo on 12 June. A few days later an agreement was concluded with Russia, providing for the joint responsibility of Pristina airport with a NATO contingent and for the participation of some 3,600 Russian troops in KFOR, reporting to the country command in each sector. On 20 June the withdrawal of Yugoslav troops from Kosovo was completed, providing for the formal ending of NATO's air campaign. KFOR's immediate responsibility was to create a secure environment to facilitate the safe return of refugees, and, pending the full deployment of UNMIK, to assist the reconstruction of infrastructure and civil and political institutions. In addition, NATO troops were to assist personnel of the international tribunal to investigate sites of alleged violations of human rights and mass graves. In January 2000 NATO agreed that the Eurocorps defence force would assume command of KFOR headquarters in April. In February, following an escalation of ethnic conflict in northern Kosovo, an emergency meeting of the NAC determined to reinforce KFOR's troop levels. In October KFOR worked with OSCE and UN personnel to maintain a secure environment and provide logistical assistance for the holding of municipal elections in Kosovo. During the year KFOR attempted to prevent the movement and stockpiling of illegal armaments in the region. In February 2008 Kosovo's newly elected government issued a unilateral declaration of independence from Serbia, supported by many EU countries. NATO’s Secretary-General and NAC at that time reaffirmed the commitment to maintain a force in Kosovo and to support any future arrangements.

Since 2008 NATO has supported the development of the Kosovo Security Force (KSF), a multi-ethnic, lightly-armed crisis response force, with responsibility for conducting civil protection operations that are outside the remit of the Kosovo police—such as explosive ordnance disposal, clearance of hazardous materials, search and rescue operations, and fire-fighting—and supporting the civil authorities in responding to natural disasters. In June 2009 NATO ministers responsible for defence announced a gradual reduction in its Kosovo Peace Implementation Force (KFOR, established in 1999) troop numbers, given improvements in the security environment. NATO and KFOR were, within the scope of their mandates, to offer support towards the implementation of an Agreement on Normalization, that was concluded in April 2013 between Kosovo and Serbia. In July of that year the NAC declared that the KSF, then numbering around 2,200 personnel, had reached full operational capability and was fully trained, to NATO standards, to perform the tasks assigned by its mandate. NATO was to continue to provide advice and support to the Force through an Alliance Liaison and Advisory Team. The schedule of KFOR troop reductions has been assessed continuously by the NAC in accordance with the security situation on the ground, rather than being deadline-driven. In April 2014 NATO reopened Kosovo’s upper airspace (closed since the 1999 conflict) to civilian air traffic flights; the Kosovo airspace was to remain under the authority of NATO/KFOR. In December 2018 the Assembly of Kosovo adopted legislation that provided for significant long-term reforms to the mandate, role and strength of the KSF; promulgating the legislation later in that month the Kosovo authorities emphasized Kosovo’s right to have a professional multi-ethnic army. The NATO Secretary-General stated regret at the decision and at its timing, while Serbia designated it an act of `political aggression’.

In May 2023 it was announced that 700 additional troops would be deployed to KFOR, in response to violent protests by Kosovan Serbs in (Serb-majority) northern Kosovo. The unrest had been prompted by the assumption of office of several ethnic Albanian mayors, further to municipal elections that had taken place in the previous month but had been largely boycotted by the Kosovan Serb community (which was demanding more autonomy). In response to an attack perpetrated by armed Serbs against the Kosovo Police in September, further troop reinforcements were deployed to KFOR. As at February 2024 there were 4,623 troops under NATO command in Kosovo (compared with 3,747 in October 2022, and with some 15,500 in January 2009), from 28 NATO and KFOR partner countries.

p-group.heading: Afghanistan
p-group.p: In August 2003 NATO undertook its first mission outside of the Euro-Atlantic area when it assumed command of the UN-mandated ISAF in Afghanistan. In October the office of a NATO Senior Civilian Representative was established to liaise with the Afghan government and representatives of the international community. In December NATO ministers responsible for defence agreed to extend ISAF's mission in Afghanistan beyond the capital, Kabul. A revised operational plan was endorsed by NATO ministers responsible for foreign affairs in December 2005. Operations were to be extended to cover the entire country and an additional 15 Provincial Reconstruction Teams, five regional commands and two forward support bases (in Kandahar and Khost) were to be established. Additional ISAF officers were dispatched to mentor and liaise with national army units, support government programmes to disarm rebel groups and support government and international programmes to counter illicit narcotic production. In September 2006 NATO’s Secretary-General signed a declaration with the Afghan President establishing a Framework for Enduring Co-operation in Partnership, committing NATO to long-term support for the country's efforts to secure democratic government and territorial integrity. In April 2009 heads of state and of government, and leaders of partner countries contributing to ISAF, attending the NATO summit, declared their long-term commitment to that country, pledged the deployment there of additional military forces for electoral support and for training and mentoring the Afghan National Army. Further initiatives to enhance the training for Afghan National Security Forces, to improve the command and control structure of ISAF and to deploy NATO airborne warning and control aircraft to Afghanistan, were approved by NATO defence ministers meeting in June. A NATO Training Mission in Afghanistan (NTM-A) was formally established in October. In February 2010 ISAF initiated a joint military offensive with Afghan national security forces in order to reassert government authority and to protect the civilian population in southern Helmand province. A joint framework for transition to full Afghan ownership of its national security by the end of 2014 was endorsed at the NATO summit meeting in November 2010. The 2012 NATO summit, held in May, determined to initiate the planning process for a new mission (`Resolute Support’) that was to continue training, advising and assisting the Afghan security forces, within the context of the Framework for Enduring Co-operation in Partnership and at the behest of the Afghan Government, following the 2014 transfer of power. A ceremony in Kabul in June 2013 marked the final transfer of command for security operations from ISAF to Afghan national security and military forces, and, following the termination of ISAF in December 2014, Resolute Support was deployed, across the country, from 1 January 2015. In April 2020 the NAC welcomed the prospect of the initiation of intra-Afghan talks, following the conclusion in February of an agreement between the USA and Afghan Taliban that was focused on achieving peace through negotiations. A statement released in July by the NAC emphasized that an Afghan-owned peace process was the only way to achieve lasting national security, reiterated NATO’s commitment to supporting this, and stressed that present levels of violence were stalling the proposed intra-Afghan negotiations process. In mid-April 2021 the NAC determined that a four-month withdrawal of NATO forces from Afghanistan would commence on 1 May; the Afghan security forces were, however, to continue to be supported, and a NATO civilian presence was to be maintained in Kabul. Upon the departure of the NATO forces the situation on the ground in Afghanistan transformed dramatically, as the Afghan National Army (ANA) proved unable to prevent a very rapid expansion of Taliban militant control over provincial centres and key strategic corridors. On 13 August the NAC met to discuss the crisis; the Secretary-General subsequently stated concern over the Taliban’s highly violent offensive, including targeted killings, other grave abuses of human rights, and attacks on civilians, and restated commitment to supporting a negotiated political solution to the Afghan conflict. On 15 August the Taliban authorities, having swiftly captured Afghanistan’s other cities, took control of the capital, Kabul, and, stated their intent to declare an Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan. The incumbent Afghan President, Mohammad Ashraf Ghani Ahmadzai, fled the country. The situation was discussed by an extraordinary meeting of the NAC that was held on 20 August, in a virtual format. In late August the Secretaries-General of NATO and of the UN participated in a virtual meeting of the Group of Seven (G7) leaders of major advanced economies to address the situation in Afghanistan. The meeting concluded that ensuring the safe evacuation of nationals and also of Afghan citizens who had provided assistance to the allied NATO forces, and supporting the ongoing international humanitarian response in the region should be prioritized. Continuing steadfast commitment to the Afghan people was affirmed.

p-group.heading: Iraq
p-group.p: In June 2004 NATO heads of state and of government, meeting in İstanbul, agreed to offer assistance to the newly inaugurated Iraqi Interim Government with the training of its security forces. Consequently, a NATO Training Implementation Mission was initiated in the following month. In December the NAC authorized an expansion of the Mission, of up to 300 personnel, and the establishment of an Iraq Training, Education and Doctrine Centre. The NATO Training Mission-Iraq (NTM-I) expanded its remit in 2010 to include training of border personnel, but was terminated in December 2011. In April 2011 Iraq was granted NATO partner status. It was announced in May 2012 that a NATO Transition Cell had been established in Iraq to support the development of the partnership. In July 2015, at the request of the Iraqi authorities, the NAC approved a package of defence capacity building measures that were to support Iraq in priority areas that included security sector reform, demining, and civil military and military medicine planning. From early 2016 NATO dispatched mobile NATO security sector reform teams to Iraq. From April NATO provided training, in Jordan, to Iraqi officers. In July the Alliance agreed to provide training, strategic advice and capacity building efforts within Iraq: these activities commenced in January 2017, alongside the Jordan-based training initiative. In July 2018, at the request of the Iraqi Government (which had declared victory over the terrorist group Islamic State in December 2017), NATO heads of state and government authorized a new NATO Mission Iraq (NMI), with a focus on training; the NMI was established in October 2018. In early January 2020 NATO temporarily suspended the mission’s activities, for safety reasons, following the assassination, on Iraqi soil, by a US air strike, of General Qassem Soleimani, commander of the elite Quds Force unit of the Iranian Revolutionary Guards Corps. Meanwhile, the global coalition against Islamic State suspended its combat operations in Iraq to focus on protecting its bases. On 6 January the Iraqi legislature passed a non-binding resolution demanding that foreign military forces withdraw from Iraq and cease using its land, waters and airspace. At that time the NAC, meeting at ambassadorial level, under the chairmanship of NATO’s Secretary-General, expressed its strong ongoing support for the NMI, and for the collective fight against Islamic State and other terrorist groups, and emphasized NATO’s readiness to resume training and capacity-building activities in future. In February 2021 NATO ministers responsible for defence determined to strengthen and expand the NMI from some 500 to 4,000 personnel, on the basis of a request by the Iraqi Government, in particular to counter the ongoing threat from Islamic State.

p-group.heading: Operation Unified Protector
p-group.p: In March 2011 NATO initiated Operation Unified Protector, using ships and aircraft operating in the Central Mediterranean, in order to monitor and enforce an arms embargo against the Libyan author­ities, which had been imposed by the UN Security Council (Resolution 1973, adopted on 17 March) in response to the violent oppression of an opposition movement in that country. Later in that month NATO members determined to enforce the UN-sanctioned no-fly zone over Libya, alongside a military operation to prevent further attacks on civilians and civilian-populated areas, undertaken by a multinational coalition under British, France and US command. A few days later, on 27 March, NATO member states agreed to assume full command of the operation to protect civilians in Libya (formal transfer of command took place on 31 March). In late October, following the capture by opposition forces of the last remaining government-controlled city, Sirte, and the arrest (and subsequent death) of the Libyan leader, Col Muammar al-Qaddafi, the NAC resolved to conclude the Operation with effect from the end of that month.

p-group.heading: Operation Sea Guardian
p-group.p: In September 2001, following the terrorist attacks against targets in the USA and the decision to invoke Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty, NATO redirected the Standing Naval Forces to provide an immediate Alliance presence in the eastern Mediterranean. In the following month Operation Active Endeavour was formally launched, to undertake surveillance and monitoring of maritime trade in the region and to detect and deter terrorist activity, including illegal trafficking. In March 2004 the NAC determined to expand the operation to the whole of the Mediterranean and to seek the support of this extension, through their active participation in the operation, by participants in the EAPC and the PfP programme. An Exchange of Letters between NATO and Russia, concluded in December 2004, facilitated the implementation from February 2006 of joint training activities. In September NATO authorized the participation of a Russian naval ship in the operation. The NAC approved the active involvement of a Ukrainian ship in the operation in May 2007. In November 2016 Operation Active Endeavour was transformed into the non-Article 5-mandated Operation Sea Guardian—a broader maritime security operation, covering further tasks, such as countering terrorism and trafficking, supporting situational awareness, and supporting regional capacity building. Operation Sea Guardian was to work closely with the EU’s Central Mediterranean-based Operation Sophia.

In November 2016 NATO’s former Operation Active Endeavour (established in late 2001) was transformed into the non-Article 5-mandated Operation Sea Guardian, a broad maritime security operation, covering tasks such as countering terrorism and trafficking, supporting situational awareness, and supporting regional capacity building.

p-group.heading: Sub-Saharan Africa
p-group.p: NATO provided logistical support to the AU Mission in Sudan from July 2005-December 2007. In June 2007 NATO agreed to support the AU Mission to Somalia (AMISOM, operational during 2007-March 2022) by providing strategic airlifts for deployment of personnel and equipment. The 2012 NATO summit agreed to extend strategic airlift support, and also maritime life support, to AMISOM. NATO conducted three anti-piracy operations off the coast of Somalia: Operation Allied Provider (in October-December 2008); Operation Allied Protector (March-August 2009); and Operation Ocean Shield (August 2009-December 2016).

int-org-section.heading: Finance
int-org-section.p: As NATO is an international, not a supra-national, organization, its member countries themselves decide the amount to be devoted to their defence effort and the form which the latter will assume. Thus, the aim of NATO's defence planning is to develop realistic military plans for the defence of the Alliance at reasonable cost.

In September 2014 NATO heads of state and government made a Defence Investment Pledge, in which they emphasized the NATO guideline of a minimum level of national defence expenditure amounting to at least 2% of GDP, and determined that this should be achieved across the organization by 2024, and also agreed to ensure a more balanced sharing of costs and responsibilities. Members contribute to the Alliance on the basis of a cost-sharing formula. The NATO civil budget for 2024 amounted to €438.1m. (a notable increase over the allocations in 2023 and 2022 of, respectively, €370.8m. and €289.1m.). The military budget for 2024 was €2,030m. (12% higher than the 2023 allocation). In 2023 Poland’s defence expenditure, at 3.9% of its GDP, was estimated to be proportionately the highest of all member states, followed by the USA (3.5%).

Under the annual defence planning process, political, military and economic factors are considered in relation to strategy, force requirements and available resources. The procedure for the co-ordination of military plans and defence expenditures rests on the detailed and comparative analysis of the capabilities of member countries. All installations for the use of international forces are financed under a common-funded infrastructure programme. In accordance with the terms of the Partnership for Peace strategy, partner countries undertake to make available the necessary personnel, assets, faci­lities and capabilities to participate in the programme. The countries also share the financial cost of military exercises in which they participate. In 2023 Poland’s defence expenditure, at 3.9% of its GDP, was estimated to be proportionately the highest of all member states.

int-org-section.heading: North Atlantic Treaty
int-org-section.heading-note: signed 4 April 1949, as amended by protocols signed on the accession of Greece, Turkey—now Türkiye, Germany and Spain

legal-block.p: The Parties to this Treaty reaffirm their faith in the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations and their desire to live in peace with all peoples and all governments.
They are determined to safeguard the freedom, common heritage and civilization of their peoples, founded on the principles of democracy, individual liberty and the rule of law.
They seek to promote stability and well-being in the North Atlantic area. They are resolved to unite their efforts for collective defence and for the preservation of peace and security.
They therefore agree to this North Atlantic Treaty:

item.p: The Parties undertake, as set forth in the Charter of the United Nations, to settle any international dispute in which they may be involved by peaceful means in such a manner that international peace and security and justice are not endangered, and to refrain in their international relations from the threat or use of force in any manner inconsistent with the purposes of the United Nations.

The Parties will contribute toward the further development of peaceful and friendly international relations by strengthening their free institutions, by bringing about a better understanding of the principles upon which these institutions are founded, and by promoting conditions of stability and well-being. They will seek to eliminate conflict in their international economic policies and will encourage economic collaboration between any or all of them.

In order more effecitvely to achieve the objectives of this Treaty, the Parties, separately and jointly, by means of continuous and effective self-help and mutual aid, will maintain and develop their individual and collective capacity to resist armed attack.
The Parties will consult together whenever, in the opinion of any of them, the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the Parties is threatened.

The Parties agree that an armed attack against one or more of them in Europe or North America shall be considered an attack against them all and consequently they agree that, if such an armed attack occurs, each of them, in exercise of the right of individual or collective self-defence recognised by Article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations, will assist the Party or Parties so attacked by taking forthwith, individually and in concert with the other Parties, such action as it deems necessary, including the use of armed force, to restore and maintain the security of the North Atlantic area.

Any such armed attack and all measures taken as a result thereof shall immediately be reported to the (UN) Security Council. Such measures shall be terminated when the Security Council has taken the measures necessary to restore and maintain international peace and security.
For the purpose of Article 5, an armed attack on one or more of the Parties is deemed to include an armed attack:

—on the territory of any of the Parties in Europe or North America, on the Algerian Departments of France
, on the territory of Turkey (Türkiye) or on the Islands under the jurisdiction of any of the Parties in the North Atlantic area north of the Tropic of Cancer;

—on the forces, vessels, or aircraft of any of the Parties, when in or over these territories or any other area in Europe in which occupation forces of any of the Parties were stationed on the date when the Treaty entered into force or the Mediterranean Sea or the North Atlantic area north of the Tropic of Cancer.

This treaty does not affect, and shall not be interpreted as affecting in any way the rights and obligations under the Charter of the Parties which are members of the United Nations, or the primary responsibility of the Security Council for the maintenance of international peace and security.

Each Party declares that none of the international engagements now in force beween it and any other of the Parties or any third State is in conflict with the provisions of this Treaty, and undertakes not to enter into any international engagement in conflict with this Treaty.

The Parties hereby establish a Council, on which each of them shall be represented, to consider matters concerning the implementation of this Treaty. The Council shall be so organised as to be able to meet promptly at any time. The Council shall set up such subsidiary bodies as may be necessary; in particular it shall establish immediately a defence committee which shall recommend measures for the implementation of Articles 3 and 5.

The Parties may, by unanimous agreement, invite any other European State in a position to further the principles of this Treaty and to contribute to the security of the North Atlantic area to accede to this Treaty. Any State so invited may become a Party to the Treaty by depositing its instrument of accession with the Government of the United States of America. The Government of the United States of America will inform each of the Parties of the deposit of each such instrument of accession.

This Treaty shall be ratified and its provisions carried out by the Parties in accordance with their respective constitutional processes. The instruments of ratification shall be deposited as soon as possible with the Government of the United States of America, which will notify all the other signatories of each deposit. The Treaty shall enter into force between the States which have ratified it as soon as the ratifications of the majority of the signatories, including the ratifications of Belgium, Canada, France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and the United States, have been deposited and shall come into effect with respect to other States on the date of the deposit of their ratifications.

After the Treaty has been in force for ten years, or at any time thereafter, the Parties shall, if any of them so requests, consult together for the purpose of reviewing the Treaty, having regard for the factors then affecting peace and security in the North Atlantic area, including the development of universal as well as regional arrangements under the Charter of the United Nations for the maintenance of international peace and security.

After the Treaty has been in force for twenty years, any Party may cease to be a Party one year after its notice of denunciation has been given to the Government of the United States of America, which will inform the Governments of the other Parties of the deposit of each notice of denunciation.

This Treaty, of which the English and French texts are equally authentic, shall be deposited in the archives of the Government of the United States of America. Duly certified copies will be transmitted by that Government to the Governments of other signatories.

int-org-section.endnote: In January 1963, the North Atlantic Council noted that insofar as the former Algerian Departments of France were concerned, the relevant clauses of this Treaty had become inapplicable as from July 1962
